metadata.titel_preek: First and Second Sunday of Advent

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The Master (God/Christ) returns to his household (the world/church) to claim his own and judge the darkness, while the household exists in a state of crisis-vigilance.

subject.identificatie: God / The One Who Comes (Jesus Christ)
tekstueel_bewijs: It is he who put the whole operation in motion
He comes; he comes at the end of the ages
God's power that gives good deeds

object.identificatie: The New Creation / Salvation of the incompetent human
tekstueel_bewijs: a power that is able to make a new creation out of people like us
The witness is from God; the light is from God; the preaching is from God

ontvanger.identificatie: The Church / 'People like us' who have no capacity
tekstueel_bewijs: people who have no capacity of ourselves to save ourselves
solidarity with other human beings who... receive mercy
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is positioned as the Receiver of mercy, not the Subject of salvation.

helper.identificatie: John the Baptist / The Preacher / The Holy Spirit (implied in prayer)
tekstueel_bewijs: The preacher is nothing; the Word is everything
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject; Christ is the Light; the Spirit provides the 'Armor of Light'.

tegenstander.identificatie: The Powers of Darkness / Sin / Human Self-Righteousness
tekstueel_bewijs: the kingdom of God is in head-on collision with the powers of darkness
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad habits but 'the whole frame of this world' and 'the works of darkness' which require a divine collision to overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical response of the believer: bearing fruit and keeping watch.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer / The Church
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program is explicitly fueled by the primary. We are 'able to repent... because he is coming.' The ability (Pouvoir) is a gift from the Primary Subject.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: John the Baptist/Preacher → God/Christ ← Powers of Darkness/Sin

voorbeelden_god_subject: He will come in the future.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We live at the turn of the ages.
The church keeps her own deep inner rhythms.

voorbeelden: He must not find us asleep.
orienting ourselves to an altogether new perspective
The Advent clock tells the church what time it is.
I need power from outside myself to make me different.
The power that is coming is not our power.
We are able to repent... because he is coming.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon acknowledges the 'Devoir' (Must) but identifies the human as lacking 'Pouvoir' (Can). It locates the 'Pouvoir' exclusively in the coming of God, making grace the source of competence.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from the 'Absence of God' (~S1) and 'False Security' (~S2) to the 'Collision' between S1 and S2, where S1 (Christ) overcomes S2.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved not by human effort but by the 'irresistible force' of the One Who Is Coming.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; darkness is described as a cosmic reality and a 'head-on collision'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It explicitly rejects the idea that human exhortation or effort can produce repentance, attributing all agency to God's external power.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: It is God’s power that gives good deeds.
The kingdom of God is in head-on collision with the powers of darkness.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: John the Baptist is used not as a moral example to follow, but as a 'witness' and a 'spotlight' that disappears to reveal Christ.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Theocentric: John is a 'beam of light' from God.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the burden of self-salvation; sober vigilance.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic sanctification (God works the change in us).

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The ethical imperatives (watch, repent) are perfectly integrated as consequences of the divine arrival.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'The Master is away' and 'The Master is at the door'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: In Jesus Christ, the kingdom of God is in head-on collision with the powers of darkness.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit (implied as God's power) provides the 'Pouvoir' that the human lacks.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is an 'absence of God' and a 'work of darkness' that humans cannot escape alone.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine is driven by God's arrival. The human is the beneficiary (Receiver) of a power they cannot generate.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The sermon already masterfully balances the 'Must' of the law with the 'Can' of the Gospel.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a textbook example of grace-oriented homiletics. It avoids the trap of 'exemplarism' and maintains God as the active Subject of the narrative.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While rhetoric might focus on the 'darkness' imagery, Greimas shows that the darkness is an Actantial Opponent that only a Divine Subject can defeat.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Greek 'metanoia'; Greimas reveals that 'metanoia' is a modal gift (Pouvoir) rather than a human work.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas exposes that even when the preacher says 'Repent!', the underlying structure ensures the power to do so comes from the 'Sender' (God).

appendices.notities: The sermon successfully navigates the 'Rutledge Rule' by making God the subject of the most critical active verbs.
